TERM: Systemic Belonging

DEFINITION:
The fundamental need for inclusion and membership within relationship systems, as described by Bert Hellinger. Belonging is a core requirement for human well-being and system health. Those who conform to system orders belong; those who violate them may be excluded, with profound consequences. The need for belonging can be so strong that people prefer unhappiness within a system to happiness outside of it. Belonging provides natural well-being, clear identity, and sense of place. In family systems, all members have equal right to belong, regardless of their actions or characteristics. Exclusion or attempted exclusion of system members creates disturbances that affect the entire system.

BLUEPRINT DETAILS:
Belonging is a fundamental systemic need. All members have equal right to belong in family systems. Exclusion creates disturbances that propagate. Application: When modeling human systems, recognize belonging as a core driver of behavior - individuals will act to maintain belonging even at personal cost, and exclusion of members creates systemic imbalances that must be addressed.

EXAMPLE APPLICATION:
In analyzing why team members tolerated toxic leadership, applying SystemicbelonginG principles revealed they preferred unhappiness within the group to potential exclusion - a pattern also seen in family systems where members maintain harmful relationships to preserve belonging.

CATEGORY: CorePrinciple
